author: flexiondotorg
body:
## PR Summary

This pull request modifies the installation instructions for Ubuntu to reference Snapcraft. The "Many Linux distributions" entry which references Snapcraft has also been moved into the supported platforms table as we've (I work on the Snapcraft team) confirmed the PowerShell snap is working across all Snap compatible distributions.

comments.author: TylerLeonhardt
comments.body: I'm going to defer this to @TravisEz13. The change is kinda inconsistent with the other items in the table - going from a file extension (like the rest) to Snapcraft... but maybe there was a conversation that went on elsewhere that said this is fine.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @joeyaiello Can you comment?  I'm not sure we want to change the primary may we are asking people to install PowerShell to snap.  At least not yet.  We just fixed an issue when VS Code would not run from the snap.  I'm still listing the snap as experimental.

comments.author: mi-hol
comments.body:
The snap install doesn't work ATM for WSL!
WSL is currently the easiest way to try LINUX distributions like Ubuntu on their own computer.
https://github.com/Microsoft/WSL/issues/2374

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Also, in containers, but often containers and WSL require additional steps

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
Yeah, we obviously love Snap, but I think we'd want to do a full test pass across Ubuntu distros using the Snap before we move them all over.

Also, has Snap been pushed into the older LTS versions as part of servicing? Or do you have any kind of idea what percent of users are pulling it in? My hypothesis is that folks on older LTS are less likely to want new dependencies (eg. Snap), but I don't have any real data there.

Lastly, the "more Linux distros" line makes sense to me in principle, and I feel like we went through the formatting and wording already with AppImage. Could we pull that up and see if it makes sense to match what we had there?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: One problem still is that we have found that distributions not supported by DotNet, we cannot guarantee are supported.  So, the line about more distributions would need to move back down to the community table.
